tasks.task: Attend an educational seminar on strawberry diseases.
subtasks: Introduce yourself as a Plant Pathologist.
Define plant diseases.
Explain biotic and abiotic causes.
Discuss preventative measures against diseases.
Detail common leaf spot diseases (strawberry leaf spot, leaf blight).
Describe management strategies for leaf spot diseases (fungicide application, resistant varieties).
Explain bacterial diseases (angular leaf spot) and their management.
Identify soil and crown rot diseases (anthracnose, phytoptera root rot).
Outline management strategies for crown and root rots (resistant varieties, sanitation).
Address fruit rots (gray mold, anthracnose, rhizobus, new diseases).
Provide cultural practices to control fruit rots (fungicide dips, picking practices).
Summarize disease prevention and management for commercial growers.
Provide contact information for further assistance.

tasks.task: Handle strawberry plants in the field.
subtasks: Examine strawberry plants for leaf spots.
Identify signs of fungal leaf spots (brown lesions, target-like patterns).
Check for bacterial leaf spots (angular leaf spots).
Inspect lower leaves for water-soaked yellow lesions.
Look for leaf blight symptoms (yellow-brown leaves, V-shaped lesions).
Examine fruit for signs of rot (gray mold, anthracnose spots).
Check the calyx of infected fruits for visible bacteria.
Monitor plants for crown and root rot symptoms (withered plants, brown crowns).
Remove dead or infected plants immediately.
Apply fungicides according to recommended schedules.
Dip transplants in fungicide solutions to prevent diseases.
Prune diseased areas of the plant.
Practice sanitation by removing fruit debris.
Monitor soil drainage and adjust planting sites.
Apply resistant varieties to reduce disease incidence.
Clean equipment and tools between plants to prevent disease spread.

tasks.task: Perform pesticide application on strawberry fields.
subtasks: Wear appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) before application.
Mix fungicide solutions according to product labels.
Calibrate pesticide sprayers for proper coverage.
Apply fungicides uniformly across the plant canopy.
Monitor weather forecasts to avoid application during rain.
Rotate fungicide products to manage resistance development.
Document application dates and products used for record-keeping.
Dispose of contaminated materials properly.

tasks.task: Manage contaminated material in the field.
subtasks: Isolate and destroy plants showing severe disease symptoms.
Bury or dispose of removed plants properly to prevent spread.
Harvest affected fruit immediately and remove from field.
Do not reuse infected transplants or propagation material.
Clean tools and equipment after use to prevent disease carryover.

tasks.task: Conduct sanitary practices in the greenhouse/nursery.
subtasks: Inspect transplants for disease symptoms before planting.
Dispose of any plants with visible pathogens.
Sterilize work surfaces and tools before handling healthy plants.
Use a fungicide dip solution to treat transplants prior to planting.
Regularly clean the growing area to remove debris.

tasks.task: Scout and monitor fields for disease progression.
subtasks: Walk through the strawberry field daily to detect new infections.
Check for emerging symptoms on young leaves and fruit.
Isolate affected areas to prevent spread.
Prune and destroy symptomatic plant parts.
Document the location and extent of disease outbreaks.
Adjust control strategies based on monitoring findings.

tasks.task: Maintain good soil and field hygiene.
subtasks: Test soil for drainage and fertility.
Amend soil as necessary to improve water drainage.
Remove crop residue after harvest.
Rotate crops to break disease cycles.
Use raised beds or mounds for better air circulation.
Handle fruit gently to avoid physical damage that can lead to rot.
Inspect fruit for signs of disease during harvest.
Remove diseased fruit immediately and dispose of properly.
Store harvested fruit in a cool, dry environment to slow decay.
Follow proper refrigeration techniques for long-term storage.
Research strawberry varieties resistant to prevalent pathogens.
Select resistant varieties based on regional adaptation and yield potential.
Test new varieties in a limited area before widespread adoption.
Document performance of resistant cultivars over multiple growing seasons.
Clean and disinfect harvesting equipment.
Discard diseased fruit and do not reuse containers on contaminated materials.
Bag and dispose of infected plant material properly.
Maintain cleanliness in storage areas to prevent contamination.
Record the date, product name, rate, and application method.
Follow label instructions regarding re-entry intervals.
Keep detailed records for future reference and compliance.

tasks.task: Communicate with agricultural experts and stakeholders.
subtasks: Share knowledge about disease identification and management with colleagues.
Participate in workshops and educational events on disease management.
Collaborate with university extension agents for crop health.
Provide feedback to product manufacturers about observed resistance issues.
Stay updated through newsletters and research articles on disease trends.

tasks.task: Attend an educational seminar on strawberry diseases.**
